title: Words From Body Parts
description: Many English expressions and words use body parts in unexpected ways. How well do you know these anatomical word connections?

questions.question: The word 'captain' comes from the Latin 'caput', meaning which body part?
The word 'muscle' derives from the Latin 'musculus', which literally means what?
What body part does the word 'courage' come from (via Latin 'cor')?
The word 'digital' comes from 'digitus', the Latin word for what?
The word 'pupil' (of the eye) comes from Latin and refers to what?
options: A little doll (the tiny reflection of yourself)

questions.question: If you 'shoulder' a responsibility, you are doing what?
What does it mean to 'foot the bill'?
The word 'abdicate' contains the Latin root for which body part?
options: It does not contain a body part root

questions.question: The word 'sincere' is sometimes said to come from Latin meaning 'without' what body-related substance?
What does it mean to 'elbow' your way through a crowd?
The word 'artery' and the word 'art' both come from a root word meaning what?
What does it mean to 'nose around'?
The word 'capital' (as in capital city) comes from which body part in Latin?
What does the phrase 'to eye something' mean?
options: To look at it with interest or suspicion

questions.question: The word 'cervical' (as in cervical vertebrae in the neck) comes from 'cervix', meaning what in Latin?
